title: MUSA 550: Final Project
text: The existing Airbnb and its price prediction platforms only consider a few basic variables, resulting in limited accuracy. This is particularly evident in Amsterdam, where chaotic pricing in the short-term rental market poses challenges for government regulation. Addressing how multidimensional data can assist renters in determining fair price ranges, encourage hosts to price reasonably, and help the government manage rental quality without bias presents an intriguing research topic.

title: MUSA 550: Final Project
text: The existing Airbnb and its price prediction platforms only consider a few basic variables, resulting in limited accuracy. This is particularly evident in Amsterdam, where chaotic pricing in the short-term rental market poses challenges for government regulation. Addressing how multidimensional data can assist renters in determining fair price ranges, encourage hosts to price reasonably, and help the government manage rental quality without bias presents an intriguing research topic.

title: Analysis
text:
Analysis
Questions to Explore: - Identifying more suitable indicators for Amsterdam (e.g., proximity to the Red Light District). - Developing more accurate, unbiased, and generalizable models for price and rating prediction.
Data Used: - Amsterdam Open Data Portal - Open Street Map - Airbnb datasets
Content: - The Analysis will show the steps about the data, model, and the application.
The Models could be used for:

Renters: Predicting fair payment expectations based on property and service conditions (price prediction model).
Hosts: Offering strategic recommendations on pricing and operations by inputting basic conditions and target pricing. For example, “Based on current market trends and your property’s quality, a price of XXX is likely to yield a rating of XX. To effectively increase your rating to XX, consider reducing the price to XXX or improving in the following areas: XX” (rating prediction model with pricing considerations).
Governments: Incentivizing properties in specific areas that meet certain quality and rating thresholds to promote market optimization. By analyzing model parameters, governments can better understand how property quality, service standards, and pricing affect ratings, enabling more precise and unbiased policy-making.

Requirement meet: - Data is collected through a means more sophisticated than downloading (e.g. scraping, API). Due to the large volume of data, the frequent loading and splitting required for debugging parameters and other tasks take an excessive amount of time. Therefore, I utilized an API to crawl the data, download it locally, and then reload it. - It combines data collected from 3 or more different sources. - The analysis of the data is reasonably complex, involving multiple steps (geospatial joins/operations, data shaping, data frame operations, etc). - Perform a machine learning analysis with scikit-learn as part of the analysis. - Project includes multiple interactive visualizations that include a significant interactive component (cross-filtering, interactive widgets, etc). Due to the excessive number of interactive maps, the application became unusually sluggish. I have converted some of them into PNGs.

Here I gathered data from Amsterdam Open Data Portal, Open Map street, Airbnb, and other resources for housing internal characteristic features and external service, amenity and in-facility features and geographical boundary information for neighborhood effect consideration. These features will form an inventory for subsequent process for different models and different subjects. I also gathered data that relating to different development context such as whether in a development area or poor area to make further comparison analysis and validation. Unrelated, invalid, false-typed and biased data are filtered out initially through common sense.
The data can be divided into 3 types, and each one is listed blow with their detailed information. Significantly, this inventory is the basic foundation, the variable library will be cleaned, updated and stated with modeling description.

1.2 Internal Inventory
First, I deconstruct the basic check in data to obtain internal features for every order, such as the date of the order real-time housing price. Then through extraction and processing, I obtained the month, the day, and the number of orders of each housing units, the real-time price (not the recommended or average price), and the total revenue the housing generated. It is a large list including 1,200,071 objects and could be used for price prediction for renters. Here, I fully excavate extensive possible internal features from text analysis and matching. There are more than 100 internal amenity key words, and host information, room numbers, availability, renting rules, order information, and evaluations. Many variables here can be the independent variables according to different models and serving subjects. In my data pool, mutiple boolean variables showing whether they have those amenities.

# Time and Order
Am_Time_B = pd.read_csv("Dataset/Basic Data/calendar.csv").dropna()
Am_Time = Am_Time_B.copy()
Am_Time['price'] = Am_Time_B['price'].str.extract(r'(\d+\.?\d*)').astype(float)
Am_Time['date'] = Am_Time_B['date'].astype(str)
Am_Time['month'] = Am_Time['date'].str[5:7].astype(int)
Am_Time['day'] = Am_Time['date'].str[8:10].astype(int)
Am_Time = Am_Time.drop(columns=['date'])
Am_Time = Am_Time.rename(columns={"listing_id": "id", "price": "pricex"})
am_time_n = Am_Time.groupby('id').size().reset_index(name='n')
Am_Time = Am_Time.merge(am_time_n, on='id', how='left')
am_time_sum = Am_Time.groupby('id')['pricex'].sum().reset_index(name='x')
Am_Time = Am_Time.merge(am_time_sum, on='id', how='left')

title: Part 2: Preliminarily Analysis
text:
Here, I preliminarily analyze those variables.

2.1 Airbnb Distribution with Housing Price
Most Airbnb housing units with high price are in near the center of the city


Code
display(Image(filename="New folder/Untitled-1.jpg"))











2.2 Categorical Variables
Important categorical variables are unevenly distributed. Some of the special class present special price distribution correspondingly. Such as the small portion of cancellation_policy, super_strict_60, corresponds to a higher price. These variables embodied a housing type diversity that can influence the price.


Code
# Figure6
Am_Basic_no_geo = Am_Basic.drop(columns=['geometry'])
selected_data = Am_Basic_no_geo[['price', 'host_response_time', 'cancellation_policy', 'room_type']]
melted_data = selected_data.melt(id_vars=['price'], 
                                 value_vars=['host_response_time', 'cancellation_policy', 'room_type'], 
                                 var_name='Variable', 
                                 value_name='value')
plt.figure(figsize=(12,10))
g = sns.FacetGrid(melted_data, col="Variable", sharex=False, sharey=False, height=4, aspect=1.5)
g.map_dataframe(sns.barplot, x="value", y="price", estimator="mean", 
                color="#aa003A", edgecolor="#aa003A", alpha=0.4)

g.set_axis_labels("", "Price")
g.set_titles(col_template="{col_name}")
g.set_xticklabels(rotation=45, horizontalalignment='right', size=10)
g.set_titles(fontsize=14)

g.fig.suptitle("Housing Price According to Categorical Features", fontsize=20, y=1.05)
g.fig.subplots_adjust(top=0.85)
plt.figtext(0.5, -0.2, "Figure 6, Housing Price According to Categorical Features", 
            wrap=True, horizontalalignment='center', fontsize=12)

plt.show()

title: Part 3: Features Engineering
text:
The external features will be further engineered into new variables. nn (the distance to the different numbers of the nearest features), price lag (the lag in price with the different numbers of the nearest housing), distance (distance to nearest slow walk system), and area (whether in a certain type of area) . Those spatial processed features and spatial effect features can generalize the model with respect proper scales. Some parameters have been determined through iteration, and they are only stated here as optimized results. Then I will combine all the variables into 2 sets: the housing set and the order information set. These two sets will be integrated into modeling process to get the best models for price, revenue, and evaluation.

3.1 Point Features Engineering
Include Knn info.


Code
# add geo-features
Am_Basic = gpd.GeoDataFrame(pd.DataFrame(Am_Basic))
Am_Basic1 = gpd.sjoin(Am_Basic, Am_Area, how="inner")
Am_Basic1 = Am_Basic1.rename(columns={"Gebied": "area"})

Am_Basic1 = Am_Basic1.drop(columns=['index_right'])

Am_Basic2 = gpd.sjoin(Am_Basic1, Am_District, how="inner")
Am_Basic2 = Am_Basic2.rename(columns={"Stadsdeelcode": "district"})
Am_Basic2 = Am_Basic2.drop(columns=['index_right'])

Am_Basic3 = gpd.sjoin(Am_Basic2, Am_Quarter, how="inner")
Am_Basic3 = Am_Basic3.rename(columns={"CBS_Wijkcode": "quarter"})
Am_Basic3 = Am_Basic3.drop(columns=['index_right'])

Am_Basic4 = gpd.sjoin(Am_Basic3, Am_Neighborhood, how="inner")
Am_Basic4 = Am_Basic4.rename(columns={"CBS_Buurtcode": "neighborhood"})
Am_Basic4 = Am_Basic4.drop(columns=['index_right'])

Am_Basic4 = Am_Basic4.dropna()
Am_Basic4 = Am_Basic4[(Am_Basic4['price'] < 3000) & (Am_Basic4['price'] >= 20)]

Am_geo = Am_Basic4[["geometry"]]

del Am_Basic1, Am_Basic2, Am_Basic3




Code
# knn
def nn_function(source_points, target_points, k):
    source_coords = np.array([(geom.x, geom.y) for geom in source_points if geom is not None])
    target_coords = np.array([(geom.x, geom.y) for geom in target_points if geom is not None])
    if len(target_coords) == 0:
        return np.full(len(source_coords), np.nan)
    tree = cKDTree(target_coords)
    distances, _ = tree.query(source_coords, k=k)
    if k > 1:
        distances = distances[:, k-1]
    return distances

Am_geo['shops_nn1'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_shops.geometry, 1)
Am_geo['shops_nn2'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_shops.geometry, 2)
Am_geo['shops_nn3'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_shops.geometry, 3)
Am_geo['shops_nn4'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_shops.geometry, 4)
Am_geo['shops_nn5'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_shops.geometry, 5)
                                  

Am_geo['playground_nn1'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playground.geometry, 1)
Am_geo['playground_nn2'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playground.geometry, 2)
Am_geo['playground_nn3'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playground.geometry, 3)
Am_geo['playground_nn4'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playground.geometry, 4)
Am_geo['playground_nn5'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playground.geometry, 5)

Am_geo['station_nn1'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_station.geometry, 1)
Am_geo['station_nn2'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_station.geometry, 2)
Am_geo['station_nn3'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_station.geometry, 3)
Am_geo['station_nn4'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_station.geometry, 4)
Am_geo['station_nn5'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_station.geometry, 5)

Am_geo['playfacilities_nn1'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playfacilities.geometry, 1)
Am_geo['playfacilities_nn2'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playfacilities.geometry, 2)
Am_geo['playfacilities_nn3'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playfacilities.geometry, 3)
Am_geo['playfacilities_nn4'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playfacilities.geometry, 4)
Am_geo['playfacilities_nn5'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_playfacilities.geometry, 5)

Am_geo['sightseeing_nn1'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_sightseeing.geometry, 1)
Am_geo['sightseeing_nn2'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_sightseeing.geometry, 2)
Am_geo['sightseeing_nn3'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_sightseeing.geometry, 3)
Am_geo['sightseeing_nn4'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_sightseeing.geometry, 4)
Am_geo['sightseeing_nn5'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_sightseeing.geometry, 5)

Am_geo['food_nn1'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_food.geometry, 1)
Am_geo['food_nn2'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_food.geometry, 2)
Am_geo['food_nn3'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_food.geometry, 3)
Am_geo['food_nn4'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_food.geometry, 4)
Am_geo['food_nn5'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_food.geometry, 5)

Am_geo['sex_nn1'] = nn_function(Am_geo.geometry, Am_sex.geometry, 1)

3.2 Polyline and Polygon Features Engineering
Here are also variables generated from polyline and polygon features that include 4 distance variables and 5 whether in certain area type variables.


Code
# line
Am_geo_sp = Am_geo.geometry
Am_walk_sp = Am_walk.geometry
Am_geo['walk'] = Am_geo_sp.apply(
    lambda geo: Am_walk_sp.distance(geo).min() * 1000
)




Code
# area_distance
Am_shopping_sp = Am_shopping.geometry
Am_protect_sp = Am_protect.geometry
Am_poor_sp = Am_poor.geometry

def calculate_min_distances(source_geom, target_geom):
    distances = []
    for src in source_geom:
        min_distance = target_geom.distance(src).min()
        distances.append(min_distance * 1000)  
    return distances

Am_geo['shopdist'] = calculate_min_distances(Am_geo_sp, Am_shopping_sp)
Am_geo['protectdist'] = calculate_min_distances(Am_geo_sp, Am_protect_sp)
Am_geo['poordist'] = calculate_min_distances(Am_geo_sp, Am_poor_sp)




Code
# area_attribute
Am_shopping["shopping"] = "yes"
Am_protect["protect"] = "yes"
Am_poor["poor"] = "yes"
Am_development["development"] = "yes"

Am_geo = Am_geo.sjoin(Am_shopping, how="left", predicate="intersects")
Am_geo["shopping"] = Am_geo["shopping"].fillna("no")
Am_geo = Am_geo.drop(columns=["index_right"])

Am_geo = Am_geo.sjoin(Am_protect, how="left", predicate="intersects")
Am_geo["protect"] = Am_geo["protect"].fillna("no")
Am_geo = Am_geo.drop(columns=["index_right"])

Am_geo = Am_geo.sjoin(Am_poor, how="left", predicate="intersects")
Am_geo["poor"] = Am_geo["poor"].fillna("no")
Am_geo = Am_geo.drop(columns=["index_right"])

Am_geo = Am_geo.sjoin(Am_development, how="left", predicate="intersects")
Am_geo["development"] = Am_geo["development"].fillna("no")
Am_geo = Am_geo.drop(columns=["index_right"])

Am_geo = Am_geo.drop_duplicates()

Am_Basic5 = Am_Basic4.sjoin(Am_geo, how="left", predicate="intersects")

All the model are for predicting the most generalizable, reasonable, while still accurate outcomes of each model. So here we should get rid of exorbitant objects of each training lists. To fully improve the model’s generalizability, accountability, and accuracy. We further adopt lag features, iterations, and selection of reasonable variables (variables that are causal and controllable by different subjects).
What’s more, to combine different training set that are interrelated but with quite different number of objects that cause the model larger than 72 GB and will crush the program, I trained housing information set first to get preliminary potential variables and then trained the order information set to ensure the final model fits well to all those sets. In this process, I conducted extensive attempts to get the most potential variables with the best parameters to obtain the model with the highest accountability, accuracy and significance.
Here is the technology map of the modeling process. All the training and test sets are 7:3 divided.

4.1 For Renters
This model is for renters to find price reference. Just by inputting the requirement, date of checking in and clicking on the map to find a preferred location, they can get a fair price according to the real-time market situation. They can avoid being overcharged or malserviced. These variables can be further classified into different level like economic choice, prime choice, luxury choice as preset options. These model shows a large commercial and market surveillance potential. To further explore the model. I introduced in time and spatial lag, and error lag for potential sequential influence.

4.2 For Hosts
There is a model system for hosts that includes 10 models. one for potential average revenue prediction, one for potential average orders prediction, 8 for evaluation prediction (one for total rates prediction with all possible variables, one for total rates prediction with sub-evaluation rates, six for sub-evaluation rates such as communication, cleanness). Here price is a independent variable. Hosts can adjust their price, setting, performance strategies to improve their total rates, revenue, order numbers, sub-evaluation rates, or check out which sub-evaluation rates influence the total rates most and find a way to improve. They can do these adjustment with consideration of cost, expectation or the government policies.

475 rows × 7 columns



Some variables are important for all host models. By sorting the variable by frequency below, we can see the common important variables are:

host performance (calculated host listing count, response time, host response rate, whether the host is a superhost, the time hosted from, whether the housing’s location is exact, whether the host’s identity is verified)
housing rules (whether it is instant bookable, cleaning fee, the cancellation policy, the maximum continuous nights you can book, long term stays allowed, smoking allowed, whether it is available in 30 days, 24-hour check-in, the maximum number of extra people in it, the maximum number of guests in it)
amenities (Lock on bedroom door, smoke detector, host greets you, iron, washer, room type, property type, suitable for events, baby bath, bed linens, carbon monoxide detector, dryer, gym, kitchen, TV)
location (in which neighborhood, the distance to the nearest 3-5 sex points, the distance to the nearest playfacility)
reviews (reviews per month, the date of the first review, the date of the last review, the scores for value, the scores of cleanliness, number of reviews)
operation situation (average price, average daily order number)

These variables prove people are more concern with safety, basic needs, the number of people the housing allowed, host performance, and host experience, whether in a good neighborhood, short-term availability, and accessibility to special experience places such as red zones and playficilities. For different outcome, people also put different extent of attention to different variables. These variables’ positive and negative influence can be checked through the analysis of the “estimates” of each variable of each model. It can better serve hosts to come up with strategies.
It also shows that people are not so demanding on the housing. Just by improving basic, proper but necessary service with flexible housing rules, controlling short-term availability properly, caring children, family, and minorities’ special needs, and excavating surrounding interesting points, they can improve their evaluations and average orders and revenue along with time, and the increase of order, and make renters feel worthy to live here.
These variables doesn’t relate to the outcome directly, but they can effect costumers’ cognition. It also shows that the accumulated orders and order frequency, and operation time can also improve the outcome. They can promote orders with some methods without decreasing service and quality, they can improve their housing overall performance along with time.
These models are not fixed with certain variables. As we imagined, the real-time data of the market of the latest time-period will continuously be put into the training of the model. Some variables could be added into consideration, and some of them could be not any more.

text:
This system and the application fully considers the possible variables (nearly 300) and different sets out comes to form a much more accurate, much less biased, much more generalizable platform for both renters, hosts and government sectors to get what they need. It’s a big step from the original calculator tool with much less controllable variables.
It is also form an internal mutual influence relationship between the renters, hosts and governments to supervise and promote each other to a better market environment in real-time.
It is not only about profit, but also quality, quantity, characteristics, efficiency, sustainability, balance development and justice.
In terms of the modeling process, the more than 20 times of iteration for the finest detail of the system ensure the systems validity.
In the future, based on the foundation, we can further develop it as a web-toolkit with cloud computing, more sophisticated models, and visualizing tools for different sectors.

Am_Basic2 = Am_Basic2.drop(columns=['index_right'])

Am_Basic3 = gpd.sjoin(Am_Basic2, Am_Quarter, how="inner")
Am_Basic3 = Am_Basic3.rename(columns={"CBS_Wijkcode": "quarter"})
Am_Basic3 = Am_Basic3.drop(columns=['index_right'])

Am_Basic4 = gpd.sjoin(Am_Basic3, Am_Neighborhood, how="inner")

Am_Basic4 = Am_Basic4[(Am_Basic4['price'] < 3000) & (Am_Basic4['price'] >= 20)]

Am_geo = Am_Basic4[["geometry"]]

As for the evaluation, no development promoting areas perform much better than development promoting areas, which prove that those areas still need Airbnb improvement especially their quality. Government should set high-evaluation incentives for them to promote their quality. There basically not difference between the two historic contexts, to improve their characteristics, the government should improve the standard for historic protecting areas and review the sub-evaluation as the same process to put up with more punishments for specific sub-evaluations to improve the characteristics. Shopping areas perform a little bit worse than areas that are not. High standard is also applicable for those areas.
Government can apply the same analysis process on sub-evaluations to put up with detailed requirements.
